content.webTitle: Q&A: John Marsden says he wouldn't write Tomorrow series now

fields.headline: Q&A: John Marsden says he wouldn't write Tomorrow series now
fields.bodyText: The author of Tomorrow When the War Began, John Marsden, says he would not have written a novel portraying the invasion by a foreign power today because of his “horror” towards Australia’s refugee policy. Speaking on the ABC’s Q&A on Monday, Marsden was forced to defend his best-selling Tomorrow series, which tells the story of a group of teenagers who band together to resist the invasion by an apparently Asian foreign power. “I wouldn’t write that book now, not because of a societal view ... but because of my own horror at the way refugees who have come to Australia have been treated,” Marsden said. “And when I hear the political debate raging today and this [is] just relegated to a footnote in the pages of hansard ... that would put me in a different position when it came to writing about threats to Australia. Because demonising people like that is unforgivable.” The comments came during a special Melbourne writers festival episode of the ABC program that also featured authors Maxine Beneba Clarke, Sofie Laguna, Michael Mohammed Ahmad and Trent Dalton. The panel was dominated by a discussion of race issues following Katter Australia party senator Fraser Anning’s incendiary “final solution” speech last week. Ahmad, who is Lebanese-Australian and grew up in western Sydney, was highly critical of Marsden’s books, saying they had been published amid “tremendous xenophobia” towards the Vietnamese-Australian community and had “genuinely impacted and damaged the lives of a lot of people”. “And when I pulled the words apart in the Tomorrow series, I did interpret a paranoid white nationalist fantasy about a group of coloured people illegally invading this country,” Ahmad said. “And I always find that narrative deeply ironic because that’s what the white population did to the Indigenous population.” Marsden replied that he was “happy for anyone to react to my work in whatever ways they react”. Dalton, a features writer for the Australian newspaper who has recently released his debut novel, Boy Swallows Universe, was critical of the decision by the Brisbane writers festival to drop Germaine Greer and Bob Carr from its lineup. “Are we getting so soft that we can’t ... handle these deep discussions?” Dalton said. Greer, who has been criticised in recent years for her views on transgender people, among other things, sparked outrage with her latest book, On Rape, while Carr’s memoir, Run For Your Life, includes his views on issues such as immigration and Israel. Greer was unavailable to appear at the upcoming Melbourne writers festival, but its director, Marieke Hardy, has said the prominent feminist was unlikely to have been invited anyway. Clarke told the Q&A audience that Greer’s current views were “not really radical”. “These are kind of really harmful, mainstream ideas that are out there, that are transphobic or rape [apologetic] or whatever,” she said. Decisions not to invite people “happen all the time”, she said, “but these are particular people that are used to being handed any platform, hence the fury”.
